Comment: I think it's the first time I've moved a knight on my first move: I thought I'd try it out for a change. Interesting that Black should do the same on his first move, but then I'd normally play 1... Nc6 as a response to 1. Nf3 when I'm black. That influenced my second move, which probably influenced Black's: a keenly contested centre.

We're keeping symmetry here, allowing our kingside bishops some freedom.
We're keeping symmetry here, allowing our kingside bishops some freedom.

This move was made to free up my queenside bishop, and to try to get out the queen: if Black takes my pawn, I take the capturer with my knight, and if black takes my knight, I take back with my queen...
...but he declines to take my pawn, enforcing the pawn trade...
...so I agree to go ahead with it...
...so I agree to go ahead with it...
...along with a pair of minor pieces: his bishop for my knight. I have one developed piece to Black's two, but I do have one more long-range piece remaining.
...along with a pair of minor pieces: his bishop for my knight. I have one developed piece to Black's two, but I do have one more long-range piece remaining.
I made this move was necessary to prevent a knight from camping on g4.
Now I get out my bishop, hoping to trade it for one of Black's knights, and get level on development...
Now I get out my bishop, hoping to trade it for one of Black's knights, and get level on development...
...which prompted Black to develop his only previously undeveloped minor piece...
...allowing me to line up his knights with my bishop...
...so I trade my bishop for a knight, to remove another threat from Black, and open up the d-file...
...so I trade my bishop for a knight, to remove another threat from Black, and open up the d-file...
...so I trade my bishop for a knight, to remove another threat from Black, and open up the d-file...

...so I can get rid of the queens. I may have surrendered the open file, here, but I thought it was best to remove Black's most powerful piece, for my king's sake, my queen capturing Black's in making the only queen move in the game...

...so I can get rid of the queens. I may have surrendered the open file, here, but I thought it was best to remove Black's most powerful piece, for my king's sake, my queen capturing Black's in making the only queen move in the game...
...but I can contest the open file with my rook. I'm hoping that Black's agreeing to go ahead with the exchange, as my king is denied access to the queenside...
...and Black did agree. He must be trying to make exchanges for the same reason, to help his own king.
...and Black did agree. He must be trying to make exchanges for the same reason, to help his own king.
Now Black has control of the open file, again. I moved the king along his starting rank along the queenside, to keep his bishop free, so it can allow his rook to contest the open file...
Now Black has control of the open file, again. I moved the king along his starting rank along the queenside, to keep his bishop free, so it can allow his rook to contest the open file...
...and I develop my bishop to the second rank to free the rook, allow my rook to contest the open file, and keep the bishop out of harm's way...
...and I develop my bishop to the second rank to free the rook, allow my rook to contest the open file, and keep the bishop out of harm's way...
...so now my rook is free to contest the open file. I'm again hoping Black will agree to exchange, which would allow my king more room to roam...
...so now my rook is free to contest the open file. I'm again hoping Black will agree to exchange, which would allow my king more room to roam...

...and Black agrees. The reason behind exchanging the six major pieces was to allow our kings more freedom on the board. If this was in a newspaper, this looks like a good position to begin analysing from: one open file (although open files are probably no longer an issue now that the major pieces are gone), with both of us having a light-square bishop, a knight, and seven pawns apiece.

I'm playing a very defensive game here, allowing Black's pawns to come at me, and hoping to catch them, stop them from slipping through the net...
...so I move up my knight's pawn to cover a4 and c4, to try to catch the pawns on those files...
